questions.question_text:
At the end of a project, you upload project documents to a Microsoft SharePoint Online library that contains many files. The following is a sample of the project document file names:
✑ aei_AA989.docx
✑ bci_WS098.docx
✑ cei_DF112.docx
✑ ebc_QQ454.docx
✑ ecc_BB565.docx
All documents that use this naming format must be labeled as Project Documents:
You need to create an auto-apply retention label policy.
What should you use to identify the files?

discussion.content:
I think this should be A.
A sensitive info type, a regular expression kan detect filename (a-z + d{3}) easy and fast.

comments.content: All methods checks for content. In this case we don't know the content, so the best thing to do is use trainable classifiers to check the content and find a pattern to identify the files. In my opinion, the question includes files names just for confuse us!

discussion.content: I tested and a sensitive info type is not able to verify the file name.

Selected Answer: A
C. A trainable classifier: Trainable classifiers are used for unstructured content and require machine learning to identify files based on examples of similar content. This approach is more suitable for text-based content rather than predictable naming conventions.

Selected Answer: C
Like everyone mentioned, SIT doesn't look at file names. Tested in my tenant.

Selected Answer: C
C is correct

Selected Answer: C
SIT doesn’t check file names, only content. It has to be a trainable classifier.

From Chat GPT: 

To automatically apply retention labels based on specific criteria, such as file names, you would typically use a trainable classifier in Microsoft 365. Trainable classifiers in Microsoft 365, specifically sensitive information types, can be trained to recognize patterns in data, including file names, and apply actions based on the identified patterns.

In this scenario, you would create a trainable classifier that recognizes the naming format of the project documents (e.g., files with names like "aei_AA989.docx"). Once trained, you can use the trainable classifier to create an auto-apply retention label policy that automatically applies the label to documents that match the specified naming pattern.

So, the correct answer is:

C. A trainable classifier

Wow, what a tricky question. Really a hard one. From all I've read, I found out that DLP policy applied to Exchange online has the option to check if file name matches a pattern. https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/purview/dlp-policy-reference

SIT definitely does not identify file names. Hence, I would also opt for trainable classifier.

Selected Answer: A
Because the question says: All documents that use this naming format must be labeled as Project Documents

I chose SIT - A

the question says that the documents are uploaded to a Microsoft SharePoint Online library
One of the requirements for trainable classifiers is: Place the seed content in a SharePoint Online folder that is dedicated to holding the seed content only. Make note of the site, library, and folder URL.
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/classifier-get-started-with?view=o365-worldwide

Since the upload can easily be used to train the classifier since many examples are in it. I agree with C.

Since we have a bunch of documnents with content that we are going to look for we can create an auto-apply label policy that will use a trainable classifier that will use documents as seed documents to find them in the future.

Selected Answer: C
Trainable classifiers work with .docx files. 

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/classifier-learn-about?view=o365-worldwide&viewFallbackFrom=o365-worldwid
The answer is C - trainable classifier.

comments.content: "How should you configure the regular expression to detect the content?" - Content, not file name.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Question #4 actually contains the answer ;)

Question #4Topic 1
HOTSPOT -
You use project codes that have a format of three alphabetical characters that represent the project type, followed by three digits, for example Abc123.
You need to create a new sensitive info type for the project codes.
How should you configure the regular expression to detect the content?

Selected Answer: A
Sensitivity info type makes more sense to me, as it's focused on just the project documents in a site with "many files". If you do a trainable classifier you'd need a large set of "good" examples and this could take a while. But if you were to create a custom sensitive info type and use regex expressions then it should be simpler to implement.

comments.content: SIT verify file names or only content of that files ?

discussion.content:
I think he has chosen the trainable classifier as it is mentioned in the question:
"you upload project documents to a Microsoft SharePoint Online library that contains many files." So the requested files are existing only in SharePoint Library. So I believe the answer is right

C is the correct answer. Everyone if focusing on the ###_ll### and not the simple .docx. 
Trainable classifiers work with .docx files. (It's that simple.) 
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/classifier-learn-about?view=o365-worldwide

Answer = A

what they want is a NAMING format, NOT the inside of the file contents as classifer is looking at contents

comments.content: Agree, I did a test and the filenames are also detected by a sensitive info type.

discussion.content: a senstive info type might do but project is organisation specific thus a trainable classifier is correct anwser

comments.content: My first thought was what, that's not true, but indeed it only checks the content not the file name.

discussion.content: Sensitive info type does not classify based on file name
I don't think so. For me A is better answer, even C should also work. Name of file have easy pattern, so sensitivi info type based on RegEx will be best choice for me

comments.content:
Why A?
Sensitive info type is for sensitive content.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AD
Why Not Teams-Specific Locations (C/E):

"Team channel messages" (C) and "Team chats" (E) apply to message text (not files). To retain the actual files, you must target SharePoint (D) and OneDrive (A).

Selected Answer: CE
To create a retention policy that retains all files from Microsoft Teams channel conversations and private chats, you should select the following two locations in the retention policy configuration:

Teams channel messages: This location includes all messages and files shared within standard and private channels of Microsoft Teams.
Teams chats: This location encompasses all messages and files shared in 1:1 or group chats outside of channels.
These selections ensure that the retention policy applies to both the files shared in team channels and the files shared in private chats, covering all possible locations where files might be stored within Microsoft Teams.

--- Copilot ---

You are correct that documents shared in Microsoft Teams chats and channels are stored in OneDrive and SharePoint. However, when creating a retention policy to retain all the files from Microsoft Teams channel conversations and private chats, you should select C. Team channel messages and E. Team chats in the retention policy. These two locations correspond to the content that you want to retain, which are the files from Microsoft Teams channel conversations and private chats. The retention policy will automatically apply to the underlying storage locations, which are OneDrive and SharePoint, where the files are actually stored.

--- Copilot ---
Retention policies for Teams has to choose Onedrive and Sharepoint to make sure that you retain all the files that gets shared in private chats and teams channels

Selected Answer: AD
Correct, A & D. The question states about files, not the conversations, so the backend is built upon OneDrive and Sharepoint Online.

Selected Answer: AD
Teams channel conversations: documents shared -> Sharepoint
Teams private chat: documents shared -> OneDrive for Bussiness
Key bit i think is "retain all the files", so I'd say ODfB and SPO. Selecting Teams locations are retention on actual chat messages, not files.

Selected Answer: AD
question is about retaining files. Files in private chats are stored in the personal OD and files in channel messages are stored in SPO.
It asks about documents and not messages, so AD. CE would be chat messages and not documents.
A and D are correct. The question was asked slightly different previously.

Selected Answer: CE
Sorry, it's not about private channel messages, but still it's not possible to mark both OneDrive/SharePoint and Teams chats/channel messages, I would go with C/E

This is wrong, it should be Teams private channel messages which is not presented as part of the answer. You only select + those when you are dealing with DLP

It's not allowed to select both Teams and OneDrive/SharePoint when creating retention policy!
Correct - ODfB stores files from 1-2-1 and private group chats. SPO stores files from Teams channels.
Looks correct. Files from private chats are stored on OneDrive, files from channels are stored on SP

questions.question_text:
You need to create a retention policy to retain all the files from Microsoft Teams channel conversations and private chats.
Which two locations should you select in the retention policy? Each correct answer presents part of the solution. (Choose two.)
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

You have a Microsoft 365 tenant that uses records management.
You use a retention label to mark legal files stored in a Microsoft SharePoint Online document library as regulatory records.
What can you do to the legal files?

choices.D: Copy the content of the files.
choices.C: Change the retention label of the files.
choices.B: Edit the properties of the files.

questions.answer_description:
When content is declared a regulatory record, restrictions are placed on the items in terms of what actions are allowed or blocked. Most actions are blocked except:
✑ Copy
✑ Open/Read
✑ Move within container
Note: Containers include SharePoint document libraries, OneDrive accounts, and Exchange mailboxes.
Note:
There are several versions of this question in the exam. The question has two possible correct answers:
1. Move the files to a different folder within the document library.
2. Copy the content of the files.
Other incorrect answer options you may see on the exam include the following:
✑ Delete the content from the files.
✑ Remove the retention label of the files.
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/records-management?view=o365-worldwide

discussion.content: Correct - D.

Regulatory records are the most restrictive record, in this case you can only copy the content of the files.
No changes can be made when you have this record retention label applied.
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/records-management?view=o365-worldwide#compare-restrictions-for-what-actions-are-allowed-or-blocked
On exam 1/20/2022

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
You create a retention label policy named Contoso_Policy that contains the following labels:
✑ 10 years then delete
✑ 5 years then delete
✑ Do not retain
Contoso_Policy is applied to content in Microsoft SharePoint Online sites.
After a couple of days, you discover the following messages on the Properties page of the label policy:
✑ Status: Off (Error)
✑ It's taking longer than expected to deploy the policy
You need to reinitiate the policy.
How should you complete the command? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

A user named User1 leaves your company, and the account of User1 is deleted from Azure Active Directory (Azure AD).
You need to create a new user named User2 and provide User2 with access to the mailbox of User1.
How should you complete the PowerShell command? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
